Hemoglobin: Protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. Low levels may cause fatigue; high levels may indicate dehydration.
Total Leukocyte Count: White blood cells that fight infections. High levels suggest infection; low levels suggest immune issues.
RBC Count: Red blood cells that carry oxygen. Low counts indicate anemia; high counts may indicate lung disease.
Platelet Count: Cells that help blood clot. Low counts increase bleeding risk; high counts increase clotting risk.
Hematocrit: Percentage of blood volume made of red blood cells. Low indicates anemia; high indicates dehydration.
MCV: Average size of red blood cells. Helps identify the type of anemia.
MCH: Average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell.
MCHC: Concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells.
Neutrophils: Common white blood cell type that fights bacterial infections.
Lymphocytes: White blood cells that fight viral infections and produce antibodies.
Monocytes: White blood cells that remove dead cells and fight chronic infections.
Eosinophils: White blood cells that fight parasites and allergic reactions.
Basophils: White blood cells involved in allergic reactions and inflammation.
Creatinine: Waste from muscle breakdown. High levels indicate reduced kidney function.
BUN: Waste from protein breakdown. Elevated in kidney disease or dehydration.
Urea: Waste from protein metabolism. High levels suggest kidney problems.
Sodium: Electrolyte regulating water balance and nerve function.
Potassium: Electrolyte crucial for heart rhythm and muscle function.
Chloride: Electrolyte that helps maintain fluid balance.
Calcium: Essential for bone health, muscle function, and nerve signaling.
Phosphorus: Works with calcium for bone health and energy production.
Uric Acid: Waste from purine breakdown. High levels can cause gout.
ALT: Liver enzyme. Elevated levels indicate liver cell damage.
AST: Enzyme in liver, heart, and muscles. Elevated in liver damage or muscle injury.
ALP: Enzyme related to bile ducts and bones. High levels may indicate liver or bone disease.
Total Bilirubin: Pigment from red blood cell breakdown. High levels cause jaundice.
Direct Bilirubin: Bilirubin processed by the liver. Elevated in bile duct obstruction.
Indirect Bilirubin: Bilirubin before liver processing. High levels suggest excessive blood cell breakdown.
Total Protein: Total blood protein. Abnormal levels indicate liver or nutritional issues.
Albumin: Main protein made by liver. Low levels indicate liver disease or malnutrition.
Globulin: Proteins including antibodies. Abnormal levels suggest immune or liver issues.
GGT: Liver enzyme. Elevated in alcohol use or bile duct problems.
Total Cholesterol: Total blood cholesterol. High levels increase heart disease risk.
LDL: Bad cholesterol that builds up in arteries. Lower is better.
HDL: Good cholesterol that removes bad cholesterol. Higher is better.
Triglyceride: Fat in blood from food. High levels increase heart disease risk.
VLDL: Carries triglycerides. High levels contribute to artery plaque.
TSH: Hormone controlling thyroid activity. High TSH indicates underactive thyroid.
T3: Active thyroid hormone affecting metabolism and heart rate.
T4: Main thyroid hormone converted to T3 for energy.
Free T3: Unbound T3 available to body tissues.
Free T4: Unbound T4 available to tissues; best test for thyroid function.
Fasting Glucose: Blood sugar after fasting. High levels indicate prediabetes or diabetes.
Random Glucose: Blood sugar at any time. High levels suggest diabetes.
PP Glucose: Blood sugar after a meal. Measures sugar handling.
HbA1c: Average blood sugar over 2-3 months. Above 6.5% indicates diabetes.
Vitamin D: Essential for bone health and immunity. Deficiency is common.
Vitamin B12: Essential for nerve function and blood production.
Folate: B vitamin essential for cell growth and DNA.
Ferritin: Stored iron in the body. Best indicator of iron deficiency.
Stored iron in the body. Best indicator of iron deficiency.
eGFR: Estimated glomerular filtration rate. Measures kidney filtering capacity. Low values indicate kidney disease.
